question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
In this problem, you are asked to find a value for the integral

\begin{align*}I = \int_0^1 x\cos(x)\,dx\end{align*} in two different ways.

(a) Use one of the integration techniques to compute the above integral
directly. (Leave your answer in terms of sines and cosines of some
number.)
sols:
Let $u=x$ and $dv = \cos x dx$. This gives $du = dx$ and $v = \sin x$.
Hence, using integration by parts, we have

\begin{align*}
\int_{0}^{1}x\cos x \, dx &= x\sin x \mid_{0}^{1} - \int_{0}^{1}\sin x \, dx \\
&= (1)\sin(1) - (0)\sin(0) - (-\cos(x))|_{0}^{1} \\
&= \sin(1) - (-\cos(1) + \cos(0)) \\
&= \sin(1) + \cos(1) - 1 \end{align*}

completing the problem.
hints: Products of functions usually fall victim to integration by parts.
